content.text: You have been provided with a U-tube containing coloured water. The U-tube has two sides, \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1
The wooden strip is supported by a stand and clamp (not shown in Fig. 1.1)
Use the pipette to slowly put oil into \(\mathbf{B}\). Wait to allow the oil to reach the water surface
The final length of the oil column above the water in \(\mathbf{B}\) is \(h\). Continue adding oil until \(h\) is approximately \(3\mathrm{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 1.3
• Measure and record \(h\)
• The height of the water level in \(\mathbf{A}\) is \(a\), and the height of the water level in \(\mathbf{B}\) is \(b\), as shown in Fig. 1.3
Measure and record \(a\) and \(b\)
a =
b =
• Calculate \(y\) using
y =
Repeat (a)(ii) with increasing amounts of oil in \(\mathbf{B}\) until you have six sets of values of \(h\), \(a\), \(b\) and \(y\)
Record your results in a table. Some of your values of \(y\) may be negative
Plot a graph of \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(h\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
It is suggested that the quantities \(y\) and \(h\) are related by the equation
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants
Use your answers in **(c)**(iii) to determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\)
Give appropriate units
P =
Q =
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the oil using the relationship
where \(R\) is a constant with value \(1.0 \text{g} \text{cm}^{-3}\)
Include an appropriate unit and give your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures
In this experiment, you will investigate the density of a liquid
Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1
Adjust the apparatus so that the rods of the clamps are approximately \(55 \text{cm}\) apart, as shown
Roll the modelling clay into a sphere
Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of the sphere
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\)
Show your working
percentage uncertainty =   .........  %

parts.label: (b)

content.text: Cut the sphere in half
Reverse the two halves and then press them together firmly around the joint between the first and second springs, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Record the number \(n\) of springs above the modelling clay
